intro: Tragacantha alatavica, commonly known as the Persian gum tree, is a flowering plant native to regions of Iran and Central Asia. It belongs to the legume family, Fabaceae, and is characterized by its distinctive yellow flowers and woody, thorny stems. The plant produces a valuable resin known as tragacanth, which has been used historically in medicine and as a thickening agent. Its leaves are trifoliate, and it thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in rocky soils.
